On Firefox4 beta12pre :
When using a javascript Prompt dialog, the size of the input is way too small.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
Try the provided test or use this :
<html>
<head>
</head>
<body>
<input type=button value="Prompt" onclick="javascript:prompt('Too small!','Don\'t you feel that this input box is way too small?');">
</body>
</html>
Actual Results:  
Too small prompt input

Expected Results:  
Larger input

I don't think I'd agree. I've never seen this prompt used for anything other than short bits of info, and once you go down the route of entering long strings a single-line textbox, no matter how wide, isn't great UI.

Is there a real-world site this is a problem on?

comments.text:
Our Intranet where prompt are used as a quick "rename" dialog for files ?
Deciding the length of the filename the user should enter is out of my scope.
But the fact that as soon as the filename is more than 3 words long make this prompt painfull to use actually is.

And i would even say the exact opposite than you :
If you need a modal dialog with a single line text input without length limitation, then the prompt is a good choice. A single javascript line to call, cross browser, perfect behavior as it automatically disable all other input on the form until completed (or cancelled).

As for UI, you should always keep simple things... simples, and use harder ones for areas where you really need them. The best way to avoid useless bugs.
